Brooklyn Historical Society
Theobald Wilson photographs
Wilson, Theobald
2013.005
11.3 Linear Feet in twenty nine binders and ten boxes
12.58 Gigabytes in 9,790 files
1918-2011 1960-2011 The collection consists of photographs taken by Theobald Wilson, a commercial photographer who was based in Brooklyn, dating from 1918 to 2011. The bulk of the collection is comprised of his commercial photography. The photographs primarily document churches (especially West Indian congregations) and fraternal organizations in the Crown Heights and surrounding neighborhoods of Brooklyn. In addition to the commercial photography, the collection also contains personal photographs, business records, photography equipment, and personal papers relating Wilson and his family.
Scope and Contents
The collection consists of photographs taken by Theobald Wilson, a commercial photographer who was based in Brooklyn, dating from 1918 to 2011. The bulk of the collection is comprised of his commercial photography. They primarily consist of photographic negatives (black-and-white and color), although there are some prints and digital images as well. The photographs primarily document churches (especially West Indian congregations) and fraternal organizations in the Crown Heights and surrounding neighborhoods of Brooklyn. In addition to the commercial photography, the collection also contains personal photographs, business records, photography equipment and personal papers relating Wilson and his family.
Biographical note
Theobald G. Wilson was born on January 10, 1923 in the San Juan Hill neighborhood of Manhattan. His mother was a Jamaican immigrant. He had two older sisters, Dorothy and Mavis. Wilson graduated from Dewitt Clinton High School in the Bronx. Before and after World War II he was a resident of the Harlem neighborhood of Brooklyn, where he befriended many political and cultural luminaries, such as Sammy Davis Jr., Percy Sutton, Al Sharpton, Alex Haley, Thelonius Monk, and Gordon Parks. Wilson enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1941 and was invited to join the 99th Pursuit Squadron, which is popularly known as the Tuskegee Airmen. He served in North Africa and Italy as a parachute rigger and took up photography during his service to document his experiences. In the late 1940s he married Marie Dowell and they had two children, Sidney and Susannah. They lived at a number of locations in Manhattan, including 63rd and Amsterdam Avenue and the Amsterdam Houses (1948-1956). They then moved to Brooklyn, residing at 909 Belmont Avenue (1956-1963), 646 Eastern Parkway (1963), Underhill Avenue, Church Avenue and Ocean Avenue, Crown Street, 199 Lincoln Road, and finally 84 Ross Street (Bedford Gardens). Wilson ran a successful commercial photography business out of his home for several decades. His clients included corporations such as AT&T and CBS, as well as numerous churches, fraternal organizations, and other organizations in Brooklyn, especially among West Indian communities. His wife, Marie Wilson, was a well-known quilter, president of the New York Quilter's Society, and was selected to coordinate the "Weaver of Dreams" quilt displayed at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change in Atlanta. Theobald was a member of the Church of St. Mark, which is located in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn. Marie Wilson passed away in 1997 and Theobald Wilson passed away in 2012.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to users without restriction.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright for photographs created by Theoblad Wilson is held by the Brooklyn Historical Society. All uses beyond fair use requires a licensing agreement as per Title 17 of the U.S. Copyright Law. Please consult library staff for more information.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of Sid Wilson and Susan Van Norton, 2013.
Processing Information
The collection has been processed to the file-level. Digital files stored on disks have been transferred to BHS's Archived Digital Assets server for preservation purposes. The bulk of the collection's photographs were rehoused by volunteers.
Related Archival Materials
The Harry Kalmus papers and photographs (ARC.046) also contains the work of a Brooklyn-based commercial photographer.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Theobald Wilson photographs, 2013.005, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Arrangement
The collection is organized into five series:
Series 1: Commercial photographs
Series 2: Business records
Series 3: Personal photographs
Series 4: Personal papers
Series 5: Photography equipment

Series 1: Commercial photographs5.3 Linear Feetin twenty nine binders, twelve folders, five oversize folders, and one oversize print12.2 Gigabytesin 9,618 files1976-2011
Arrangement
Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
The series contains photographic negatives (black-and-white and color), prints, and digital images that were created by Wilson for his commercial photography business. The photographs date from 1976 to 2011, with the bulk of the photographs dating from 2001 to 2011. In addition to the photographs, the series also contains some business records relating to the photography shoots and ephemera relating to the organizations that are featured in the photographs (sometimes featuring Wilson's work).
The photographs predominantly document churches and congregations in the Crown Heights and surrounding neighborhoods of Brooklyn, especially the Church of St. Mark (1417 Union Street), St. Gregory the Great Roman Catholic Church (224 Brooklyn Avenue), and Cornerstone Baptist Church (289 Lewis Avenue), among several others. The photographs document events (such as confirmations and first communions), church groups, and individuals. Notable individuals include Rev. Calvin Bess (Bishop of Trinidad and Tobago), Rev. E. Don Taylor (third bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of the Virgin Islands and assistant bishop in the Episcopal Diocese of New York), and Rev. John Holder (Anglican Archbishop of the West Indies).
Other subjects include fraternal organizations (Independent United Order of Mechanics, Deborah Grand Chapter of the Empire State), day care centers, schools and alumni events, birthdays and anniversaries, and health care organizations. Wilson was a member of the Tuskegee Airmen, and the series contains photographs of relating to the Claude B. Govan Tri-State Chapter of Tuskegee Airmen, a non-profit organization that promotes the legacy of the airmen and the spirit of aviation and science among young people.
The series also contains portraits of several notable New York politicians and judges, including David Dinkins, Ed Koch, Percy Sutton, Oliver Sutton, Al Sharpton, Fritz Alexander, Susan D. Johnson Cook, and Robert T. Arrangement
Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
The series contains a small assortment of records relating to Wilson's commercial photography business, dating from the 1960s to 2008. It also includes records relating to his pension and welfare funds as a member of the Graphic Communications International Union Local 119B.Supreme Printing Co. and SETAB brochures1960s314Promotional prints1968-1987315Business records1975-1988316Business cardcirca 1980s317Graphic Communications International Union Local 119B, New York pension and welfare funds1984-2007318Family groups proof/samples1998319Computer class - Cathedral Adult Education School19993110Photoshop notes2003-20043111Dale and Susan thank you for making our 25th Anniversary celebration special (Audio DVD)20083112Series 3: Personal photographs1 Linear Feetin three binders, one manuscript box, and one half manuscript box0.379 Gigabytesin 172 filescirca 1920s-2010
Arrangement
Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
The series contains photographs of Wilson's family and friends, dating from circa 1920s to 2010. It includes photographic negatives, prints, transparencies, and Polaroids. The bulk of the photographs document his immediate family: his wife Marie, son Sidney, and daughter Susan. Marie's work as a quilter and bag maker is well documented in the series. Of particular note are images of the "Weaver of Dreams" quilt that was featured at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change. Wilson's passion for the outdoors is also well documented. This includes fishing trips, such as local outings to Sheepshead Bay and Jamaica Bay, as well as trips to New England and North Carolina. It also includes photographs documenting trips to Medusa, New York and rifle shooting. Finally, the series includes photographs documenting Wilson's trip with other Tuskegee Airmen to President Barack Obama's inauguration in January 2009.Family and otherscirca 1920s-2000301Fishing1943-1995302Theobald, family, and friends1952-1984303Sidney and Susan B. Arrangement
Arranged chronologically.
Scope and Contents
The series contains a small assortment of personal papers that belonged to Wilson, dating from 1918 to 2011. They include records relating to his wife's family (the Dowells), passports and other licenses, a record of a burglary of his home at 199 Lincoln Road, 84 Ross Street housing records, and papers relating to the Tuskegee Airmen.Dowell family records1918-19913013Passports, licenses, medical appointment cards, etc.1923-1980s3014The Sultan Social Club annual fall dance program19393015Du Sable High School invitation19403016199 Lincoln Road burglary report and photographs1980301784 Ross Street housing records2005-2007311Tuskegee Airmen (two folders)1998-2011312-3Series 5: Photography equipment4 Linear Feetin fours boxes and one foldercirca 1950s-2000s
Arrangement
The items in this series are not arranged in any particular order.
Scope and Contents
